George_Morgan_(singer):
{{short description|American singer-songwriter}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2020}} {{More citations needed|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = George Morgan | image = George Morgan.jpg | caption = | image_size = | birth_name = George Thomas Morgan | birth_date = {{birth date|1924|6|28}} | birth_place = [[Waverly, Tennessee]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|1975|7|7|1924|6|28}} | death_place = [[Madison, Tennessee]], U.S. | instrument = Vocals, guitar | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | occupation = Singer-songwriter | years_active = 1949–1975 | label = [[Columbia Records|Columbia]], [[Starday Records|Starday]], Stop, [[Decca Records|Decca]], [[MCA Records|MCA]] }} '''George Thomas Morgan''' (June 28, 1924 – July 7, 1975){{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|page=276}} was a mid-20th-century American [[country music]] singer. He is a member of the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]] and a former member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]]. He is best known for his 1949 hit single "[[Candy Kisses (George Morgan song)|Candy Kisses]]". He was the father of singer [[Lorrie Morgan]], who is also a country music star. ==Biography== Morgan was born to Zachariah "Zach" Morgan and Ethel Turner in [[Waverly, Tennessee]], United States, but was raised in [[Barberton, Ohio]]. He was, along with a few other contemporaries (most notably [[Eddy Arnold]] and [[Jim Reeves]]), referred to as a "[[crooner|country crooner]];" his singing style being more similar to that of [[Bing Crosby]] or [[Perry Como]] than that of [[Ernest Tubb]] or [[Lefty Frizzell]]. Morgan was a member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] since 1948, and is best remembered for the Columbia Records song "[[Candy Kisses (George Morgan song)|Candy Kisses]]", which was a No. 1 hit on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country music chart for three weeks in 1949. He also had several hits based on a "rose" theme: "[[Room Full of Roses]]", "[[Red Roses for a Blue Lady]]", and "Red Roses From the Blue Side of Town". His version of "Almost" (1952), written by Vic McAlpin and Jack Toombs, was Morgan's second million selling record.{{cite book | first= Joseph | last= Murrells | year= 1978 | title= The Book of Golden Discs | edition= 2nd | publisher= Barrie and Jenkins Ltd | location= London | page= [https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/61 61] | isbn= 0-214-20512-6 | url-access= registration | url= https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/61 }} In the early 1950s he hosted a 15-minute radio program syndicated nationally by [[Ralph D. Foster|RadiOzark Enterprises]] in [[Springfield, Missouri]]. In 1974, Morgan was the last person to sing on the stage of the [[Ryman Auditorium]], before the Grand Ole Opry moved to the new Grand Ole Opry House. A week later, he was the first to sing on stage at the venue. ==Death == He died in 1975 of a heart attack after undergoing [[Cardiac surgery|open heart surgery]], and was interred in the [[Spring Hill Cemetery (Nashville)|Spring Hill Cemetery]] in [[Madison, Tennessee]]. ==Personal life == His daughter, country music singer [[Lorrie Morgan]], released two songs as duets with her late father dubbed in: "I'm Completely Satisfied" (1979){{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/george-morgan-mn0000650525/biography|title=George Morgan | Biography & History|website=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=August 8, 2021}} and "From This Moment On" (2006). ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable" !
